mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="x(n)=\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}{{s_{k}}{e^{j(2\pi{f_{k}}n\Delta t)}}+w(n)},n=1,2,\cdots," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>K</mi></munderover><mrow><msub><mi>s</mi><mi>k</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>k</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>w</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">⋯</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: As a super-resolution subspace technique, ESPRIT has favourable robustness to noise \cite{roy1989esprit}. So we choose ESPRIT as the first step of our method. The detailed process is omitted here. After using ESPRIT for one sub-Nyquist sample sequence, we obtain $K$ generalized eigenvalues $\eta_{k}(k=1,2,\cdots,K)$ corresponding to different $f_{k}$, i.e. $\eta_{k} = {e^{j2\pi {f_k} \cdot a/{f_H}}}$.\footnote{Here we assume that the generalized eigenvalues are in one-to-one correspondence with the frequencies.} Denoting the principal argument of $\eta_{k}$ as $Arg(\eta_{k})$, we obtain the estimation from the sub-Nyquist samples
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="x(n)=\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}{{s_{k}}{e^{j2\pi{f_{k}}\cdot na/{f_{H}}}}+w(n)},n=1%
,2,\cdots." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><munderover><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mi>K</mi></munderover><mrow><msub><mi>s</mi><mi>k</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>k</mi></msub></mrow><mo>⋅</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>a</mi></mrow><mo>/</mo><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>H</mi></msub></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>w</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>n</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">⋯</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: In the case of under-sampling the values of $a\cdot f_k/f_H$ may be greater than 1 for some $k$. Due to the periodicity of trigonometric functions, a series of estimated frequencies $\tilde{f}_{k}$ all satisfy ${e^{j2\pi {\tilde{f}_k} \cdot a/{f_H}}}=\eta_{k}$. The $\hat{f}_k$ are only a part of possible frequencies in the bottom of the frequency range $(0,f_H)$. We restrict the under-sampled ratio $a$ to be a positive integer. All the possible frequencies (we call eligible frequencies) can be unfolded as
prevtext: As a super-resolution subspace technique, ESPRIT has favourable robustness to noise \cite{roy1989esprit}. So we choose ESPRIT as the first step of our method. The detailed process is omitted here. After using ESPRIT for one sub-Nyquist sample sequence, we obtain $K$ generalized eigenvalues $\eta_{k}(k=1,2,\cdots,K)$ corresponding to different $f_{k}$, i.e. $\eta_{k} = {e^{j2\pi {f_k} \cdot a/{f_H}}}$.\footnote{Here we assume that the generalized eigenvalues are in one-to-one correspondence with the frequencies.} Denoting the principal argument of $\eta_{k}$ as $Arg(\eta_{k})$, we obtain the estimation from the sub-Nyquist samples
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="{\hat{f}_{k}}={Arg(\eta)\cdot f_{H}}/{(2\pi a)},k=1,2,\cdots,K." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">^</mo></mover><mi>k</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>A</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>η</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>⋅</mo><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>H</mi></msub></mrow><mo>/</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>a</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">⋯</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>K</mi></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
\subsection{The Matching of The Frequencies}
Obviously, it's almost impossible to determine the correct frequencies through only one sub-Nyquist sequence. If another sequence sampled at the rate $f_{S2}=f_{H}/b~(b>1)$ is utilized, another set of eligible frequencies can be obtained, namely

\subsection{The Matching of The Frequencies}
Obviously, it's almost impossible to determine the correct frequencies through only one sub-Nyquist sequence. If another sequence sampled at the rate $f_{S2}=f_{H}/b~(b>1)$ is utilized, another set of eligible frequencies can be obtained, namely

where $(\ast)'$ denotes the parameters related to the second sample sequence. The sets of the eligible frequencies ${\tilde f_k}$ and ${\tilde f'_k}$ contain the same group, which is composed of the correct frequencies. nexttext: According to B\'{e}zout's identity, when $a$ is coprime to $b$ (i.e. $a\perp b$), (\ref{eq7}) has integer solutions $\alpha_{m},\beta_{l}$ as long as its right hand side is an integer. Moreover, since $\alpha_m\in \{0,1,\cdots,a-1\}$ and ${\beta}_{l}\in \{0,1,\cdots,b-1\}$, the equation (\ref{eq7}) just has an unique satisfactory solution. prevtext: According to B\'{e}zout's identity, when $a$ is coprime to $b$ (i.e. $a\perp b$), (\ref{eq7}) has integer solutions $\alpha_{m},\beta_{l}$ as long as its right hand side is an integer. Moreover, since $\alpha_m\in \{0,1,\cdots,a-1\}$ and ${\beta}_{l}\in \{0,1,\cdots,b-1\}$, the equation (\ref{eq7}) just has an unique satisfactory solution. Denoting the true values of $\alpha_{m},{\beta_l}$ by $\bar{\alpha}_{m},\bar{\beta}_l$, we have

{e^{j2\pi{f_{1}}n\Delta t}},\cdots,\\

n\Delta t}}]^{T}." display="block"><mtable displaystyle="true" rowspacing="0pt"><mtr><mtd columnalign="left"><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>𝒔</mi><mo mathvariant="bold" stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mi>s</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">⋯</mi><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>s</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>f</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">⋯</mi><mo>,</mo></mrow></mrow></mtd></mtr><mtr><mtd columnalign="right"><mrow><msub><mi>s</mi><mi>K</mi></msub><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>K</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">⋯</mi><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>s</mi><mi>K</mi></msub><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mi>j</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>f</mi><mi>K</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><msup><mi/><mi>T</mi></msup><mo>.</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>

nexttext: where the column vectors of $\bm U_{s}$ and $\bm U_e$ are, respectively, the eigenvectors that span the signal subspace and the noise subspace of $\bm R_{\bm{x'x'}}$ with the associated eigenvalues on the diagonals of $\bm \Lambda$ and ${\sigma '}^2{\bm I}$ ($\bm I$ is the identity matrix), and $[\ast]^{H}$ denotes the conjugate transpose operation. So the pseudo-spectrum with respect to $\tilde{f}_{k}= g_k\cdot f_H+\alpha_k \cdot f_H/a$ can be given by
